title: 110_s3348
content: The "Emmett Till Unsolved Civil Rights Crime Act of 2008" calls for the expedited investigation of unsolved civil rights murders and provides resources for thorough investigations. Congress emphasizes the importance of timely action due to the passage of time and the age of potential witnesses. The Attorney General designates a Deputy Chief in the Criminal Section of the Civil Rights Division responsible for coordinating investigations and prosecutions of violations of civil rights statutes resulting in death before December 31, 1969. The Deputy Chief may coordinate with State and local law enforcement officials. The Attorney General conducts an annual study of cases under the Deputy Chief's jurisdiction. The Attorney General conducts an annual study to determine the number of open investigations for violations of civil rights statutes before December 31, 1969, new cases opened, unsealed Federal cases charged, and cases referred to State or local law enforcement agencies. The annual study conducted by the Attorney General includes information on cases resulting in State charges, jurisdiction, dates of charges, cases closed without Federal prosecution, attorneys working on cases, and grant applications submitted. The Attorney General will prepare and submit a report to Congress every 12 months containing the results of a study on grant applications, awards, and expenditures. The Attorney General will designate a Supervisory Special Agent in the Civil Rights Unit of the FBI to investigate violations of civil rights statutes resulting in death before December 31, 1969. The Agent may coordinate with State and local law enforcement officials. The Attorney General may provide grants to State and local law enforcement agencies for expenses related to investigating and prosecuting criminal offenses involving civil rights that resulted in a death before December 31, 1969. $2,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2008 to 2017 for this purpose. In addition to grants for investigating civil rights offenses resulting in death before December 31, 1969, the Attorney General is authorized $10,000,000 annually from 2008 to 2017 for prosecuting such violations. The Community Relations Service of the Department of Justice is also allocated $1,500,000 for fiscal year 2008. The Department of Justice allocated $1,500,000 annually from 2008 onwards to the Community Relations Service for providing technical assistance in investigating violations of civil rights statutes. SEC. 7. DEFINITION OF CRIMINAL CIVIL RIGHTS STATUTES. The term "criminal civil rights statutes" in this Act refers to specific sections of the United States Code related to conspiracy against rights, deprivation of rights under color of law, federally protected activities, involuntary servitude, peonage, and Fair Housing Act violations. These statutes were enforced by the Criminal Section of the Civil Rights Division of the Department of Justice before December 31, 1969. SEC. 8. SUNSET. Sections 2 through 6 of this Act will end at the close of fiscal year 2017. SEC. 9. AUTHORITY OF INSPECTORS GENERAL. Title XXXVII of the Crime Control Act of 1990 is amended to include a new section on the authority of inspectors general. SEC. 3703 of the Inspector General Act of 1978 authorizes Inspectors General to utilize staff to assist the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children in reviewing inactive case files and conducting further investigations. However, activities must not interfere with the Inspector General's duties, and no additional funds are allocated for this purpose. The Attorney General is authorized to reprogram funds from congressionally directed spending items to carry out the Adam Walsh Child Protection and Safety Act of 2006 if Congress does not provide adequate funding.
